content.question: Suppose a researcher wants to use a confidence interval to estimate an unknown population proportion <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is not a correct statement?

choices.label: The endpoints of the interval can vary with each new sample.
The probability that <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is in the interval is equal to the level of confidence for the interval.
Whether the interval captures <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is not known with certainty.

The population proportion <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is fixed, but the sample proportion <math alttext="p hat" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math> can vary from sample to sample.
The interval either does or does not capture <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The probability that <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is in the interval is equal to the level of confidence for the interval.
